Aspirin.description: NO Potential interaction between Paracetamol and Aspirin.

Warfarin.description: Acetaminophen increases effects of warfarin by anticoagulation. Use caution/monitor.

Ciprofloxacin.description: NO Potential interaction between Paracetamol and Ciprofloxacin.

Omeprazole.description: NO Potential interaction between Paracetamol and Omeprazole.

Warfarin.description: Aspirin increases effects of warfarin by anticoagulation. Modify Therapy/Monitor Closely. Avoid coadministration of chronic high-dose aspirin. Aspirin's antiplatelet properties may increase anticoagulation effect of warfarin.

Amoxicillin.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Amoxicillin.

Ibuprofen.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Ibuprofen.

Metformin.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Metformin.

Lisinopril.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Lisinopril.

Amlodipine.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Amlodipine.

Ciprofloxacin.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Ciprofloxacin.

Omeprazole.description: Potential interaction between Aspirin and Omeprazole.

Amoxicillin.description: Potential interaction between Warfarin and Amoxicillin. Use Caution/Monitor. Amoxicillin increases effects of warfarin by Other (see comment). Comment: Amoxicillin may enhance anticoagulant effect of vitamin K antagonists.

Ibuprofen.description: Either increases effects of the other by pharmacodynamic synergism. Modify Therapy/Monitor Closely. Drugs with antiplatelet properties may increase anticoagulation effect of warfarin.

Metformin.description: NO Potential interaction between Warfarin and Metformin.

Lisinopril.description: NO Potential interaction between Warfarin and Lisinopril.

Amlodipine.description: NO Potential interaction between Warfarin and Amlodipine.

Ciprofloxacin.description: Ciprofloxacin increases effects of Warfarin by unspecified interaction mechanism. Use Caution/Monitor.

Omeprazole.description: omeprazole will increase the level or effect of warfarin by Other (see comment). Use Caution/Monitor. Warfarin's less potent R-enantiomer is metabolized in part by CYP3A4 (and also CYP1A2 and CYP2C19). Monitor INR more frequently if coadministered with inhibitors of these isoenzymes and adjust warfarin dose if needed.
